title: The lilac sunbonnet :
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: She's a awfu' woman to talk, though a rale guid mither to me. Forbye, she canna tak' the besom to ye like yer ain wife — the wife o' yer bosom, so to speak — when ye hae been to the Black Bull. It's i' the natur' 0' things that a man maun gang there by whiles ; but on the ither haund it's richt that he should get a stap ta'eu oot o' his bicker when he comes hame, an' some way or ither the best 0' mithers haena gotten the richt way o't like a man's ain wife."

title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: She's a awfu' womanto talk, though a rale guid mither to me. Forbye, she canna tak'the besom to ye like yer ain wife--the wife o' yer bosom, so tospeak--when ye hae been to the Black Bull. It's i' the natur' o'things that a man maun gang there by whiles; but on the itherhaund it's richt that he should get a stap ta'en oot o' his bickerwhen he comes hame, an' some way or ither the best o' mithershaena gotten the richt way o't like a man's ain wife."

title: The lilac sunbonnet :
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " You see, the way o't is this, sir : yin's mither — (an' mind, I'm far frae sayin' a word agin my ain mither — she's a guid yin, for a' her tongue, wliilk, ye ken, sir, she canna help ony mair than bein' a woman ;) but ye ken, that when ye come hame frae the Black Bull, gin a man has only his mither, she begins to flyte on [scold] him, an' cast up to him what his faither, that's i' the grave, wad hae said, an' niayb'^ on the back o' that she begins the greetin'. Noo, that s no comfortable, ava.

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: She's a terrible woman to talk, though a rale guidmither to me. Forbye, she canna tak' the besom toye like yer ain wife—the wife o' yer bosom, so tospeak—when ye hae been to the ' Black Bull.' It's i'the natur' o' things that a man maun gang there bywhiles; but on the ither haund it's richt that heshould get a stap ta'en oot o' his bicker when hecomes hame, an' some way or ither the best o' mithershaena gotten the richt way o't like a man's ain wife."

title: A poor American in Ireland and Scotland /
author: Goodkind, Ben.
snippet: They are doing a good business today. Among these is the Black Bull, the White Hart, and one or two others of lesser renown. There are also many old fashioned  stores, restaurants, business establishments, lodging houses, etc., along the Grassmarket and also a police station, which is necessary, for this is a pretty tough locality.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: Jamie Alurray's marriage was a great affair, avery great affair, both for him and Blinkbonny.. forit was a " house-heating" and a " home-coming'combined; and, despite Airs. Eankine's strongly-expressed desire to have everything as quiet as possible,the arrangements were left to young Benjie Cranstoun,Beck Eiddell, and George Lockhart, with generalinstructions " to see that everything was mensefu' an'wisehke, an' to hae a royal supper in the ' Black Bull.' "

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: " Then, on the morrow's morn, when ye rub yerelbow, an' fin' forbye that there's something on yerleft shoother-blade that's no on the ither, ye tak' aresolve that ye'll come straught hame the nicht. Then, at e'en, when ye come near the ' Black Bull,'an' see the crony that ye had a glass wi' the nichtafore, ye naturally tak' a bit race by juist to get onthe safe side o' yer hame. I'm hearin' aboot newfangled folk that they ca' ' temperance advocates,'Maister Ralph, but for my pairt gie me a lang-shankitbesom, an' a guid-wife's wullin airm !"

title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: "Then, on the morrow's morn, when ye rub yer elbow, an' fin'forbye that there's something on yer left shoother-blade that'sno on the ither, ye tak' a resolve that ye'll come straught hamethe nicht. Then, at e'en, when ye come near the Black Bull, an'see the crony that ye had a glass wi' the nicht afore, yenaturally tak' a bit race by juist to get on the safe side o' yerhame. I'm hearin' aboot new-fangled folk that they ca' 'temperanceadvocates,' Maister Ralph, but for my pairt gie me a lang-shankitbesom, an' a guid-wife's wullin airm!"

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: drank tea and had indeed a very pleasant afternoon. Walked home between eight and nine, and on my arrival found a line from Lord Elgin at the Black Bull, who told me of the arrival of himself and family in Glasgow. I felt it too late to call upon him, and so I spent a pleasant three hours with preparation  for Sabbath, and went to bed about twelve.

title: Reminiscences
author: Carlyle, Thomas
snippet: Father and mother returning from some visit (probably to Nitbsdale) along with her (age say four), at the Black Bull, Edinburgh,  and were ordering dinner. Waiter, rather solemn personage,  inquired, " And what will little missy eat ?" " A roasted bummbee"  (humming or field bee), answered little missy.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: It was in the old Black Bull Inn at Jedburgh that the meeting tookplace. There had been a Head Court that forenoon to determine the listof voters for the year, and a large and already somewhat convivialcompany assembled afterwards in the dining-room of the Black Bull. Wineflowed, and as the evening waned, guest after guest prudently tookhimself off, till of the original party there were left but five--SirGilbert, Colonel Stewart, two officers of the Royal Regiment of NorthBritish Dragoons (the Scots Greys), and the proprietor ofTimpendean--the latter described in the evidence as being "very noysie."

title: Waverley Novels. (Abbotsford edition.)
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: " At Marchthorn!" exclaimed Dame Dods," heard ever man the like o' that! — And wheredid ye put up in Marchthorn ? an ane may makbauld to speer." « At the Black Bull," replied Tyrrel. " Ay, that's auld Tam Lowrie's — a very decentman, Thamas —■ and a douce creditable house —nane of your flisk-ma-hoys—I am glad ye madechoice of sic gude quarters, neighbour ; for I ambeginning to think ye are but a queer ane — yelook as if butter wadna melt in your mouth, but Isail warrant cheese no choke ye.

title: Stories of the Border Marches

title: The house with the green shutters,
author: Brown, George Douglas
snippet: He turned once more. But Wilson and the Templar had witlulrawn discreetly to the Black Bull; the street wasna canny. Gourlay resumed his way, his being a dumb gowl of rage.

title: The house with the green shutters,
author: Brown, George Douglas
snippet: " I saw him in the Black Bull yestreen," said Brodie,  who had been silent hitherto in utter scorn of the lad they were speaking of — too disgusted to open his mouth. " He was standing drinks to a crowd that were puffing him up about that prize o' his."

title: The house with the green shutters,
author: Brown, George Douglas
snippet: — Yess, I am inclined to think that he was a little too fond of Hegel." Mrs. Eccles, listening from the Black Bull door, wondered if Hegel was a drink.

title: The Dew of Their Youth
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: At any rate it was none such bad news to send by the carrier, who put upat the Black Bull in the Grassmarket, down to my mother and grandmotherin Eden Valley. I wrote to them separately, but to my father first,because he understood such things and I knew that his heart was set onFreddie and myself, though he thought (and rightly) that I was a mereclodhopper at my books compared to Fred.

title: Spare hours.
author: Brown, John
snippet: Our guard, I must say, came and looked in upon me at each stage, comforting me greatly with some jargonelle pears, the smell and rehsh of which I can feel now. I fell asleep, of course, and when we stopped  at the Black Bull, found myself snug in the potentate' s groat-coat. All this impressed me the more, when I heard of his death many years after.

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: P. S. You will observe by the date of my letter, I have already left the Black Bull. I write from one of the most comfortable hotels I ever was in, and have already ascertained the excellence of the port.

title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)
snippet: Noo, that's no comfortable, ava. A man that gangs to theBlack Bull disna care a flee's hin' leg what his faither wad haesaid. He disna want to be grutten ower [wept over]; na, what hewants is a guid-gaun tongue, a wullin' airm, an' a heather besomno ower sair worn."

title: Memoirs of William Hazlitt.
author: Hazlitt, William Carew
snippet: Mr. lla/litt casually heard of her arrival from Mr. Bell, but they did not apparently meet, though Mr. H. was at the Black Bull that Sunday, as will be seen presently. He wrote off to Mr. Patmore on the same day :—

title: Memoirs of William Hazlitt.
author: Hazlitt, William Carew
snippet: landed safe a1 Leith. A laddie brought my luggage with nir to tit.- Black Bull, Catherine Street, Edinburgh. hiiicd at three on mutton chops.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: Went to Dumlathan to breakfast, and found that Lord Elgin had gone from it yesternight. Walked to the Black Bull, where I found the whole party returned from the West. Told them that I would call again ; and in the meantime visited Mr. Elder's school at the Saltmarket.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: He remains till the Lochlomonders return, and, in the meantime, goes to Mr. M'Intosh this evening. I left the Black Bull, and made a number  of visits upon the sick. Came home after seven, calling on John Smith on my return, and getting my usual convoy from him.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: 1 2. Black Bull, where we all sat down to dinner about seven o'clock. The party was much gratified, in particular Lady Elgin, who, on the subject of machinery, was quite intelligent.

title: The Lilac Sunbonnet: A Love Story
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)

D'ye thinkshe needs to luik roon' to ken a' aboot the Black Bull? Na, na,she kens withoot even turnin' her heid.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " Ah," he said, " you were then too young to remember. But we — we that were of the Douglases, who saw them ride gaily through that gate, with the Black Bull already killed for their funeral feast, we have neither forgotten nor forgiven — be we knight or knave, cottar or churchman,  abbot or archer ! "

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: They were, however,  on the wing for Loch Lomond and the West Highlands, but say they will be back in three or four weeks. I went down to the Black Bull with them, and saw them on board of the steam-boat at four. Mr. Grey is a very fine like young man.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: I would dine with them in the Black Bull, and give them all their other accommodation in my own house. They were, however,  on the wing for Loch Lomond and the West Highlands, but say they will be back in three or four weeks.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: He is a very learned man of the same kind of eminence with Biot. They left me about ten, having taken up their lodgings at the Black Bull, to which place indeed I convoyed them.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: I preached both times. I took the bath in Harley's after the afternoon sermon, then dined at home, then called on John Smith, then went with him to the Black Bull, then got Lady Elgin to go to Mr. Wodrow's school, where Lord Elgin came soon afterwards in his gig. Mr. Wodrow was greatly embarrassed, and matters did not go on promisingly.

title: An American four-in-hand in Britain /
author: Carnegie, Andrew
snippet: Almost every house in that square offered entertainment for man and beast. Here is a true copy of names of inns noted in a few squares in the village : " Fighting Cocks," " Packhorse," " Red Lion," " Dog and Duck," " Black Lion," " Deerhound," " White Hart," " Green Lion," " Pig and Whistle," " White Lion," " Black Bull," " Elephant and Castle," " Lamb and Lark," " The Fish." If the whole village were scanned there would be beasts enough commemorated  in its inns to make a respectable menagerie.

title: Letters and memorials of Jane Welsh Carlyle.
author: Carlyle, Jane Welsh
snippet: 'Hoots! who else could it be? ' Dear, funniest of created Jamies ! While he was ostler at the ' Black Bull,' Edinburgh, ' one of them what-ye- call bagmen furgotted his patterns ' at Haddington, and he (Jamie) was 'sent to take them up; and falling in talk with him at the "Star," it came out there was no waiter, and so in that way,' said Jamie, ' we came back to the old place.' He told me all sorts of particulars ' more profitable to the soul of man ' than anything 1 should have got out of Mr. Charteris in three years, never to say ' three weeks.'

title: The complete poetical and prose works of Robert Burns:
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: I shall wait you Tuesday all day. I shall be found at Davies's Black Bull inn. I am hurried, as if hunted by fifty devils, else I should go to Greenock ; but if you cannot possibly come, write me, if possible, to Glasgow, on Monday; or direct to me at Mossgiel by Mauchline ; and name a day and place in Ayrshire, within a fortnight from this date, where I may meet you.

Wull ye speak a word for a puir body, Miss Lyndsay V Old Daniel chuckled, and rubbed his elbow, for he thought of his half-year's rent, and the welcoming face of old Robert Carrick in that small dim cabin in his own Ship Bank, close to the Black Bull, Trongate, Glasgow.

title: The Black Douglas
author: Crockett, S. R. (Samuel Rutherford)

title: Rab and His Friends and Other Papers
author: Brown, John
snippet: How well I remember the very corner of the room in Biggar manse, forty years ago, when from him 1 got the first shock and relish of humour; became conscious of mental tickling; of a word being made to carry double and being all the lighter of it. It is an old story now, but it was new then: a big, perspiring countryman rushed into the Black Bull coach-office, and holding the door, shouted, "Are yir insides a' oot?" This was my first tasting of the flavour of a joke.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.

title: Heads and tales, or, Anecdotes and stories of quadrupeds and other beasts chiefly connected with incidents in the histories of more or less distinguished men /
snippet: Patrick was telling, so the story goes, that there were four " Bull Inns " in a certain English  town. "There are but three," said a native of the place, who knew them well ; " the Black Bull, the White Bull, and the Ked Bull, where is the fourth ? " " Sure and do you not know, the Dun Cow the best of them all ] " replied the unconscious Milesian.

title: The Itinerant;
author: Ryley, S. W.
snippet: Fox, whose birth-day anniversary commemoration,  was to be held the next day at the Black Bull.

title: Peter's letters to his kinsfolk.
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: My evil genius, in the shape of an old drivelling  turnpike-man, directed me to put up at the Black Bull, a crowded, noisy, shabby, uncomfortable  inn, frequented by all manner of stagecoaches  and their contents, as my ears were well tauo'ht before mornine;. Havinfj devoured a tolerable breakfast, however, I began to feel myself  in a more genial condition than I had expected,  and sallied out to deliver one or two letters of introduction, and take a general view of the town, in a temper which even you might have envied.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: Rose at eight. After breakfast called upon Lady Elgin at the Black Bull. Preached in the forenoon the first part of my sermon on dissipation.

title: The house with the green shutters,

title: The house with the green shutters,
author: Brown, George Douglas
snippet: It was only his self-conscious bigness, of course, that made even inanimate things seem the feeders of his greatness. As Gourlay, always alive to obscure emotions which he could never express in words, mused for a moment over the strange new feeling that had come to him, a gowsterous voice hailed him from the Black Bull door. He turned, and Peter Wylie, hearty and keen like his father, stood him a drink in honour of his victory — which was already buzzed about the town.

author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "At the Black Bull," replied Tyrrel. " Ay, that's auld Tam Lowrie's—a very decentman, Thamas—and a douce, creditable house—naneof your fliskmahoys—I am glad ye made choice ofsic gude quarters, neighbour ; for I am beginning tothink ye are but a queer ane—ye look as if butterwadna melt iu your mouth, but I sail warrant cheeseno choak ye.—But I'll thank ye to gang your waysinto the parlour, for I am no like to get mickle mairout of ye it's like ; and ye are standing here just inthe gate, when we hae the supper to dish."

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: " Here's a letter for ye, Jess," Saunders said, importantly, handing her Ralph's missive. " He seemed raleagitatit when he brocht it in to me, but I cheered himup by tellin' him how ye wad dreel him wi' the besomshank gin he waur to gang to the 'Black Bull' i' theforenichts."

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: Noo, that's no comfortable, ava. A man that gangsto the ' Black Bull' disna care a flee's hin' leg what hisfaither wad hae said. He disna want to be gruttenower ; na, what he wants is a guid-gaun tongue, awullin' airm, an' a heather besom no ower sair worn."

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: ' I'll dawtie ye, rinnin' rakin' to thepublic-hoose wi' yer hard-earned shillin's. Dawtie !'quo' she ; ' faith, the " Black Bull's " your dawtie !'"

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: Say, for instance, he hae been a'day at jobs up i' the yaird, an' it's no been what yemicht ca' pleesant crunchin' through green wudan'waur whiles. Noo, we'll say that juist as a precaution,ye ken, ye hae run ower to the ' Black Bull' for agless or twa at noo's-an'-nan's."

title: The Black Douglas ... Second impression.
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: In an hour the Avondale Douglases were ready toride to the assistance qf their cousins. Alas, that EarlWilliam would take no advice, for had these and othersgone in with him to the fatal town, there would havebeen no Black Bull's Head on the Chancellor's dinnertable in the banqueting-hall of Edinburgh Castle.

title: Heads and Tales : or, Anecdotes and Stories of Quadrupeds and Other Beasts, Chiefly Connected with Incidents in the Histories of More or Less Distinguished Men.
author: Various
snippet: Patrick was telling, so the story goes, that there were four"Bull Inns" in a certain English town. "There are but three," said anative of the place, who knew them well; "the Black Bull, the WhiteBull, and the Red Bull,--where is the fourth?"--"Sure and do you notknow, the Dun Cow--the best of them all?" replied the unconsciousMilesian.

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: It's fairErastianism—it's tieranny—it's persecution. It mak'san odds even to me, for I often gaed in wi' some o'our maist respectable famdies frae the country, an' Iused to pass the ' tween sermons' wi' them in the' Black Bull;' an' forbye, I'm determined to tak'Bob Battray, the landlord, before the Shirra fordefinition (sic) o' chara'ter."

title: More Bits from Blinkbonny. ... Second edition
author: Strathesk, John
snippet: The Eev. Mr. Morrison tied the knot; and NicolFairbairn, with his bagpipes, headed the procession tothe " Black Bull." On its way, the Laigh Eoad Parliament swelled its ranks.

title: Memoirs of the life and writings of Thomas Chalmers...
author: Hanna, William
snippet: I conducted part of the examination. We returned to the Black Bull at eight, when I took leave of them.

title: The lilac sunbonnet :
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: " Gang to the Black Bull ! — what div ye mean, ye gom-

title: The lilac sunbonnet :
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: eril ? — Saunders I mean ; ye ken weel that Maister Pedeu wadna gang to ony Black Bull."

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: hoos a' thing been gaun on wi' ye the day ?' D'yethink she needs to luik roon' to ken a' aboot the' Black Bull' ? Na, na, she kens withoot even turnin'her heed. She kenned by yer verra fit as ye cam' upthe yaird.

title: Lilac Sunbonnet
author: Crockett, Samuel Rutherford.
snippet: " Gang to the ' Black B ull'!—what div ye mean, yegomeril ?—Saunders I mean; ye ken weel that MaisterPeden wadna gang to ony 'Black Bull.'"

title: Memoirs of William Hazlitt.
author: Hazlitt, William Carew
snippet: this I am drinking tde at the Black Bull, celebrated in Blackwood. It is owing to your letter.
